utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: My friend, you know her, in Houston say, bless his heart.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Bless his heart.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: OK, Laura, the big news.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Big news out of that debate is Bernie's attempted resurgence.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And his stamina, he was up there for all that time, including a big endorsement, a big rally with AOC. Raymond is going to be the reporting it for us. And quickly moving into pop star status within the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She is more than a pop star, Laura. She already has a comic book from a company called Devil's Due. Look, they have got three editions. There is also a children's book that just hit the shelves, and get this, AOC is soon to be an action figure. I wish I was making this up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I've got an action figure.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: A group called FCTRY and an activist are producing these action figures.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I thought they would look like her. That doesn't look like her.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It's a kind of airbrushed AOC. AOC is not alone. They are adding to their line, Laura. It already includes Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and others. Hillary, Obama, and there's a little Trump, too. So this is really --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, Hillary?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But let me tell you what's going on here.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That Hillary looks like Laura Bush.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You touched on earlier in the show. AOC isn't endorsing Bernie Sanders. She's endorsing the people supporting Bernie Sanders. She's trying to collect them for her next run.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She is running for president. She's going to run for president.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She wants to be queen of the left, and that is what she's attempting to do by endorsing him.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She's too young, she's only 30. But she's going to run for president, and I think this is setting it up.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: OK, from make-believe action figure heroes to the real thing. I sat down this week with Saints linebacker Demario Davis in New Orleans. utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You wear a "Man of God" headband. It got you into a little bit of hot water for the NFL. Why did you do it knowing that they have a ban on personal statements on the uniform?

utterances.speaker: DEMARIO DAVIS, NEW ORLEANS SAINTS LINEBACKER
utterances.utterance: So I thought the headband was good because I've been wearing it since week one. And it's under the helmet, so it's not really knowing or paying attention. I wasn't really clear about the rule, like if it was covered up or if it was out and exposed, and so when I got the fine I was just like, oh, man.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You decided to appeal it.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And then you try to turn it into something else.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I was in a conflict. So I'm like, man, this is strongly what I believe, and I can't do it, and because it says what it says I really don't want to take it off. And then I was like, it would be a problem for me to be obedient and follow the rule. And so I did that. But then I said, God is going to get glory from this headband whether I wear it or not. I didn't know what that meant, and all of a sudden, me and my team, we came up with the idea of marketing the headbands and using them for donations. And I have a partnership with Saint Dominic's who I've been helping raise money for their emergency room. I said why don't we just get the proceeds to go to them. Now it's over $60,000 has been raised.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And you've got a matching grant.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: And there's a matching grant that the hospital has for every dollar that's raised up to the next $1 million. So now it's up to $120,000. I would have never thought this whole movement would have happened. And it's not just here in New Orleans. It's been national.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM

utterances.speaker: LEBRON JAMES, LOS ANGELES LAKERS FORWARD
utterances.utterance: I don't want to get into a word or sentence feud with Daryl, but Daryl Morey, but I believe he wasn't educated on the situation at hand. And he spoke. And so many people could have been harmed, not only financially but physically, emotionally, spiritually.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So in other words, LeBron thought, kind of, that the Rockets' GM should Morey have shut up and managed. An uproar ensued, even among his most ardent supporters and fans. So yesterday, LeBron he tried to defend his pro-China stance.

utterances.speaker: LEBRON JAMES, LOS ANGELES LAKERS FORWARD
utterances.utterance: It's a tough situation that we're all in right now. There's issues all over the world, and I think the best thing we can do is, if you feel passionate about it, talk about it. If you're not, you don't have a lot of knowledge about it or you don't quite understand it, I don't think you should talk about it, because that just puts you in a tough position.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Especially LeBron, who if he speaks out against the Chinese regime would risk losing millions of dollars, more than any other player in the league, certainly. He has a massive deal with Nike and a big movie release in China waiting in the wings. All the money has made Mr. Social Justice rethink the wisdom of wading into politics, at least some politics. And he is sounding a little bit more like me.

utterances.speaker: LEBRON JAMES, LOS ANGELES LAKERS FORWARD
utterances.utterance: I would be cheating my teammates by continuing to harp on something that won't benefit us. I'm trying to win a championship, because that's what we're here for. We're not politicians.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I couldn't have said it better myself, but I already did. So at the end of the night, it seemed tensions were getting kind of hot. This is a good old Joe addressing Liz.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I agreed with the great job she did, and I went on the floor and got you votes. I got votes for that bill. I convinced people to vote for it. So let's get those things straight, too.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What did that tell you?

utterances.speaker: TONYA REIMAN, BODY LANGUAGE EXPERT
utterances.utterance: So the topping is authority, it's enforcing, it's I feel strong about this, but it's also anger. And when you're looking, see how his facial expression reads anger, and what did they do? They both pull apart and just release eye contact. And one of the things that Joe Biden makes a point of doing is pivoting his body towards the prison he is speaking to, and in this case, after he realized she was disrespecting him without even giving him eye contact, he pivots his body away as well.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Does the tight thumb, it's kind of like a tomahawk chop almost toward. I actually didn't mean that as a pun. I swear I didn't mean that. It just came out.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: When you have your hand closed like this, it's more emphasis. So if you open up your hands, now you're really angry. This is more emphatic.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tonya, you also noticed this about Elizabeth Warren when she was talking about the wealth tax last night. Watch.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: And all I'm saying is, you make it to the top, the top one-tenth of one percent, then pitch and two cents so every other kid in America has a chance to make.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Why was she up here?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: So a lot of people don't understand her gestures, but her gestures actually follow her words. So when she's talking about, if you are up here financially, then her hand goes up here. And when she talks about what you need to do, she moves her hands in and out because that's her way of demonstrating the framing of her thought process. So her hand movements aren't really as wild as some might think they are. They're actually thought out.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, I actually think some of the candidates, the hands don't go with the words, so I will take anything I can get at this point. All right, Tonya, how about this from Amy Klobuchar going after Warren.

utterances.speaker: SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR, D-MINN., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I'm tired of hearing whenever I say these things, oh, it's Republican talking points. You are making Republican talking points right now in this room by coming out for a plan that is going to do that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: A little shaky in the voice and more pointing.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Right. So when she gets, when she first starts off, Amy, she normally has a little bit shake to her voice, and then as she speaks a little bit more, gets a little bit comfortable, the shake tends to go away. Then when she gets passionate or frustrated or angry, you hear the shake again, and here you even hear a little bit of a breathiness in her voice.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Tonya, you also pointed out Beto O'Rourke, speaking of someone who can't gesticulate in the right way, looking down after he got a shellacking from Mayor Pete. What does this tell us? Watch. It's just b- roll. We're just showing the b-roll of it. There it is. Look at it now.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Here's the interesting thing. When we are watching, you have to realize, nonverbals, it's all about perception, right. So it's not that he was submissive in this clip. So then he looks down and he kind of pouts his mouth, and then he starts shaking his head. See that slight head negation. utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: He was angry.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Look it was -- he was angry.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: People do this for emphasis all the time, so that is just one more extra point for Joe.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, Tonya, fascinating. Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.utterance: Thank you.
